text: Carrageenan ( CGN ) is a high molecular weight sulphated polysaccharide derived from red seaweeds .
In rodents , its degraded forms ( dCGN ) can induce intestinal inflammation associated with macrophage recruitment and activation .

The aim of this study was : 1 ) to analyze the size - dependent effects of dCGN on colon inflammation in vivo , and 2 ) to correlate these effects with monocyte / macrophage proliferation , cytokine production and expression of various cell surface antigens including <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> adhesion molecule <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Peripheral blood monocytes ( PBM ) and THP-1 monocytic cells were cultured in the presence of either 10 or 40 kDa , dCGN .
The 40 kDa , but not the 10 kDa dCGN , induced colitis in in vivo .
Degraded CGN inhibited THP-1 cell proliferation in vitro , arresting the cells in G1 phase .
In addition , dCGN increased <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in both PBM and THP-1 cells with a major effect seen after 40 kDa dCGN exposure .

text: Also , dCGN stimulated monocyte aggregation in vitro that was prevented by incubation with anti-ICAM-1 antibody .
Finally , dCGN stimulated <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and secretion by both PBM and THP-1 cells .

text: All these effects were linked to NF-kappaB activation .
These data strongly suggest that the degraded forms of CGN have a pronounced effect on monocytes , characteristic of an inflammatory phenotype .
